title: Scalable End-user Access to Big Data
segmentation: So I'm going to talk about the project Optic scalable and user access to big data.
And Optic is really about a paradigm shift.
For data access.
You know it's about putting the power.
Or of big data analytics into the end of the end user.
So, but before I go there a couple of words, what metadata of the project Optic is in large scale integrating project and IP funded underframe programs happen by the European Union?
It's really a large project with a budget of almost 14 million euros, which translates to around 100 man years.
Yes, so there's really a significant investment into this project.
We have a great consortium with ten partners, academic partners, industrial partners.
Or the project is pretty much just started job.
So we started and after 2012 and the project will run until November 2016.
So much of what I'm talking about will actually be looking into the future and talking about what we want to do.
And.
Moderate what we're going to do.
I want to spend a couple of words about the use cases that we have in the project.
Now I'm in the very lucky position that in two of the keynotes that we had at this conference.
We actually had present us from the companies that provide our use cases in.
So yesterday you heard about the big data challenges at sat on and just in the beginning of this session you heard about.

Yeah, in industrial applications of big data at Siemens both Siemens and start oil are in our consortium's case study partners and I want to spend a couple of words about the concrete use cases and datasets that we're dealing with their own.
So at Siemens we are operating with Siemens Energy Services and Siemens Energy Services.
They yeah they have a service centers that are responsible for the monitoring and diagnosis of power plants.
So each of these service sends us covers thousands of turbines and you have heard a lot about these turbines already today and with the kind of data that they produce.
High volume, high velocity data.
That is relevant in this particular use case.
It's not oil.
We're working in the space of oil and gas exploration.

So we are working with the domain experts in geology, geophysics that develop stratigraphic models of unexplored areas, and in developing these models they have to access well large data from previous productions from previous explorations of similar areas.
And the kind of data that we have there is in the order of petabytes, typically highly structured relational data that is spread over thousands of tables with very complex schemata.
In numerous databases so.

So what is common to these two use cases, besides the fact that we're dealing with a large volume of data, is that the data access is extremely difficult and costly, so the estimates are that up to 70 to 80% of the time that the experts are spending is actually spent on data access problems.
Also, what this means for the for the end users for engineers in this case here is that data access is extremely slow or we have very high turn around time.
So foreign you given information need it takes up to days.
In the case of state or even up two weeks in the case of demons to get to the actual results for a new information later.
So why is that?
What are the challenges involved here?
So the.
Problem here really is that the data access is so complex that.
We always have to go through it experts so at the end users engineers have an information need but we have to go through it.
Experts that are actually able to interpret this information need an translate this information into specialized queries over these complex, disparate sources.
So the challenges that are involved there are not only volume or you're probably familiar with this diagram.
We've seen a similar diagram in the Demons presentation before.
This is how Gardner characterizes the dimensions are involved in in big data, so volume is one of them.
But here we are really dealing also with the dimension of complexity, complexity in the information needs in the schemata in the data.
We also have the challenge of variety, various data modalities, structured, unstructured etc and then obviously also the challenge of velocity.
So what is the optic approach with optic?
We really want to get this turn around times down from weeks to hours.
By enabling the end user to access big data directly without the need of an IT expert in between.
And in optical we follow the approach of ontology based data access.
The basic idea there is that the engineer would interact with the optics system through a conceptual model in the form of an ontology.
And this conceptual model basically describes the domain in terms that the domain experts understands, so not in terms of tables and columns, but in terms of relevant concepts and relationships.
And part of this ontology based data access approach is then that these queries against these conceptual models and then automatically translated into.
Queries over these desperate sources, so for example into SQL queries.
Um?
So what are the kind of tech?
Weeks that are involved here to to make this possible.
So this is looking at the.
Topics that we're working on in OPTIC.
So one important area of techniques is related to end user oriented query interfaces.
Here that really make it easy for the end user to formulate queries over these conceptual models.
So there we are, building on established techniques, for example query by navigation graph based query constructs, construction and so on.
But also developing new techniques that are more interactive with interactive query construction, interleaving with visual data exploration etc.
Then we're working on aspects of scalable Pro rewriting, so this these techniques from ontology based data access.
They have been researched for quite some time already and have been applied in practical scenarios.
But here we really have a new dimension of scale, and we're extending these rewriting techniques to deal in particular with these scenarios where we have a high number of distributed databases.
Also, new dimension here is that of streaming data which has to be considered in the query writing as well.

We're looking at techniques for query valuation with Elastic Cloud so so massively parallel query execution on elastic cloud infrastructures, and we're developing techniques for real time stream processing, so I already mentioned that a lot of the data is is temporal data, so we're extending these techniques with operators for temporal data analysis, developing techniques for scalable stream processing, event recognition.
Etc.
So how does this look like in the architecture?
I don't want to go in.
So much detail but just want to outline on a very high level the conceptual architecture that we are following you.
Let me see if the pointer is working a little bit.
So on the bottom of this architecture is the actual data sources.

Data that is spread over various databases but also streaming data on the top of this diagram that you see the user roles that are involved and you also see the separation between the end user and the expert and very central to this architecture are the ontology and the mapping.
So the ontology to capture the domain knowledge.
The mappings that essentially yeah.
Describe how these conceptual models are met to the underlying data sources.
Now the idea expert in this architecture is only needed for the ontology and mapping management.
He is not involved, is not needed for the query formulation.
The query formulation is directly done by the end user against the ontology and these queries against the ontology are then transformed using query rewriting techniques into queries over these.
Involve data sources.
We then have a component for query planning where the result is then distributed query plan that can be evaluated over these data sources in.
Yeah, using cloud based infrastructures.
On yeah, maybe how much time do I have?
Maybe one more sentence regarding the ontology.
Of course, this ontology has to be developed.
And but there were only lucky position again that we don't have to develop these ontologies from scratch.
There a lot of existing data models, tenant ontologies or models, perhaps not in the form of an ontology, but close it already available.
So a lot of the work that we do is actually on bootstrapping leverage leveraging what is already there and bootstrapping ontologies from these available resources.
OK.
Couple of words about the implementation.
We don't start from scratch.
There's a lot of.
Drone technology that the partners bring into the project.
We, as fluid operations are responsible, responsible for the systems integration and we will develop the optic solution based on the fluid drops platform that we already have in place.
If loops platform is a platform for.
Cloud management on the one hand, and semantic data management on the other.
So with this platform we are able to.
Manage.
The resources covering the entire stack of resources, including let me use the pointer again.
Infrastructure resources, so storage resources, compute resources, etc.
As well as data resources, enterprise data sources, as well as open data sources.

In this platform we heavily utilized virtualization and semantic technologies, virtualization essentially for being able to manage and provision all resources as a service infrastructure as a service software as a service, but also data as a service and semantic technologies.
Basically for the integration across this entire stack and this.
Capability of the platform to really cover both the cloud management aspects and then the data management aspect is highly relevant.
For for Optic I mentioned this problem of.
Query evaluation using elastic cloud infrastructure.
So what we're for, for example, are able to do is if we have a highly dynamic workload, so based depending on the workload at runtime, we're able to provision new resources.
For example in the form of virtual machines.
And yeah, and.
Really implemented list icity on.
Level now, so we already have products in place on top of this fluid OPS platform and optic will be a new solution that will integrate the results from the various research partners.
Your.
Words about commercialization.
We're screwed up so also responsible for the commercialization of the results.
And we're not going to do that alone.
We are in the process of building an optic ecosystem which consists of developers, users as well as partners.
So at the core of this ecosystem, we have well, the core partners are in the partners and fluid apps as a systems integrator, we have then the early adopters, primarily our case study partners and.
We already have an established, established partner network in this partner network.
You also see you see, for example Schlumberger and Halliburton, which are very obviously active in the oil and gas domain.
So our initial focus is on the energy sector energy vertical.
But in principle the techniques that we're developing also applicable in other verticals as well.
But this is where we start.
This is not a closed ecosystem.
Contrariar also building up an object partner program, so we're in this partner program.
We have various levels of partnerships to address different partner needs.
And I'm already, I've already used my time, so if you are interested in learning about the partner program or OPTIC.
General, we have an exhibition booth in the exhibition area so there couple more people from the optic project here, so we're happy to talk to you at the booth.
And perhaps there's a time for questions now.
Otherwise I will be available at the booth.
